children.name: to win a race, competition etc
win
children.definition: towina race, competition, election etc, for example by getting more points, votes etc than everyone else or by being the first to finish: chiến thắng
examples: ▪ No-one really expected the Socialist Party to win.

children.name: win a race/game/election etc
examples: ▪ Chang won the first set but lost the next two.
▪ The competition was won by a Nigerian student.

children.name: win a prize/medal/cup etc
examples: ▪ His book won the Pulitzer Prize for literature.
▪ What would you do if you won $1 million?
win by 6 votes/2 goals etcwin by getting 6 votes etc more than the other person or team : thắng hơn bao nhiêu phiếu/điểm...
▪ He went ahead of Nolan, winning by 15 seconds.
win 4-2/20-12 etcuse this to show the final result of a game :
▪ Do you remember our first game of the season? We won 3-1.

children.name: win at cards/chess/tennis etc
examples: ▪ She always wins at Scrabble.

children.name: finish first/come in first/come first UK
children.definition: to win a race or competition in which more than two people or teams are competing:
examples: ▪ Who do you think will finish first?
▪ The British team was first, followed closely by the Americans.
▪ André Etienne came in first, having completed the course in record time
finish first/be first/come in first in
▪ An Australian runner came first in the marathon.
▪ Sue finished first in two races -- the 50m backstroke and the 100m front crawl.

children.name: first/second/etc place
children.definition: the position of the person or team that wins a race or competition:

children.name: in first/second/etc place
examples: ▪ Johnson finished in first place, narrowly ahead of Green.

children.name: win first/second/etc place in
examples: ▪ My greatest achievement was winning first place in the Young Artist competition.

children.name: get in
children.definition: British if a political party gets in, they win an election, and have the right to form a government: thắng
examples: Do you think Labour will get in again at the next election?

children.name: to win a fight, war, argument, etc
win
children.definition: to argue, fight etc more successfully than someone else:

children.name: chiến thắng
examples: ▪ The court case has been dragging on for months, and it’s increasingly unlikely that she’ll win.
▪ I could never win an argument with my father.
▪ Who won the first Civil War?

children.name: win a victory
examples: ▪ This was the first of many victories won by women’s rights campaigners.

children.name: come out on top U
children.definition: come out on top informal to win sth, especially sth that other people arejudgingordeciding:
examples: ▪ In a survey of customer preference, one model came consistently out on top.
▪ In all action movies, the hero always comes out on top.

children.name: prevail
children.definition: if anideaorway of doing sthprevails, it is finally accepted as being better or more important than something else, especially after a lot of arguing: thắng thế
examples: ▪ Fortunately, in this case, common sense has prevailed.

children.name: prevail over
examples: ▪ She seems to think that animal rights should prevail over everything else.

children.name: carry the day
children.definition: British to win by persuading people to accept a plan, proposal, or idea, especially after a lot of talking and arguing:

children.name: chiến thắng ( nói về một kết hoạch, ý tưởng sau khi thuyết phục mọi người )
examples: ▪ Anti-gun campaigners feel they have enough support to carry the day in tomorrow’s vote.
▪ His appeal to reason and common sense was what finally carried the day.

children.name: win the day
children.definition: British to finally win an argument or political struggle, especially when this has beendifficult - used especially innewsreports:

children.name: chiến thắng ( nói về một cuộc tranh luận, đấu tranh chính trị , thường dùng trên báo )
examples: ▪ On this occasion the strikers won the day and were given a pay increase of 20%.

children.name: to be winning a game, race etc that has not yet finished
be winning
children.definition: to have more points or votes than your opponents in a game or election, or to be at the front in a race when the game, race etc has not yet finished: đang dẫn đầu, đang thắng
examples: ▪ Senna was winning when the race was brought to a halt because of a crash.

children.name: be winning sth
examples: ▪ It looked as though Bush was winning the election battle.

children.name: lead
children.definition: /be in the leadB2 to be winning a game, race, election etc: đang dẫn đầu, đang thắng
examples: The High School team were leading with 60 points.
The Dolphins are still in the lead with only 2 minutes left to play.

children.name: lead by 10 points/three meters etc
examples: Agassi was leading by two sets when rain stopped play.

children.name: ahead
children.definition: be  to be doing better than sb else in a game, competition, race, or election: đang dẫn đầu, đang thắng
examples: ▪ She was still ahead in the polls just a week before the election.

children.name: be ahead of
examples: ▪ Waylan was ahead of Miller by three shots.

children.name: put sb ahead
examples: ▪ Shortly afterwards Smith put the Dodgers ahead with a stunning home run.

children.name: be 12 points/5 games etc ahead
examples: ▪ Damon Hill is now 14 points ahead of his nearest rival.

children.name: by way ahead
examples: ▪ By the final lap, Molly was way ahead of all the other girls.

children.name: be ahead by 12 points/5 games etc
examples: ▪ Houston was ahead by 3 points at half-time.

children.name: the result of a game, competition, or election
result
children.definition: the final number of points, votes etc at the end of a competition, election etc. In British English, result can also be used to talk about the end of a game or sports match:
examples: ▪ It was a really exciting game, and the result was 2-1 to West Germany.
▪ These are excellent results for the Christian Democratic Party.

children.name: score
children.definition: the number of points that each team has at the end of a game or competition:

children.name: điểm số
examples: ▪ At the end of the game, the score was 32-15.
what’s the score :điểm số thế nào rồi ?
▪ What was the score?

children.name: final score:điểm chung cuộc
examples: ▪ The final score was 2-1 to Juventus.

children.name: victory
children.definition: when a country, player, team etc wins a battle, game, race etc: chiến thắng
examples: The crowds were celebrating Italy’s victory.
We’re very confident of victory.
victory over/against
the Raiders’ 35–17 victory over St Louis
victory for
The court’s decision represents a victory for all women.
a military victoryone of the General’s most famous military victories
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say'get victory'or'get the victory'. Saywin a victoryorwin victory.

children.name: a great/major victory
examples: He said the court’s decision was a great victory.

children.name: an easy victory
examples: Arsenal expected an easy victory.

children.name: a decisive victory
examples: The battle was a decisive victory for the US.

children.name: a landslide victory
children.definition: a win by a very large amount in an election
examples: No one had anticipated such a landslide victory.

children.name: a crushing victory
children.definition: a win by a very large amount
examples: Australia won a crushing 139-run victory over the West Indies.

children.name: a narrow victory
children.definition: a win by a small amount
examples: A general election on Oct. 5 produced a narrow victory for the People’s Progressive Party.

children.name: an election/electoral victory
examples: The Democrats were celebrating their election victory.

children.name: a moral victory
children.definition: when you show your beliefs are right, even if you lose the argument
examples: The victims’ families claimed the verdict as a moral victory.

children.name: win/score a victory
examples: Today we have won an important victory.

children.name: lead somebody to victory
examples: She led her team to victory in the finals.

children.name: clinch victory
children.definition: finally win
examples: Adams scored a last-minute goal to clinch victory.

children.name: pull off a victory
children.definition: win when it is difficult
examples: Martin pulled off a surprise victory in the semi-final.

children.name: sweep to victory
children.definition: win easily
examples: Nixon swept to victory by 47 million votes to 29 million.

children.name: victory celebrations
examples: The victory celebrations went on all night.

children.name: a victory parade
examples: They intend to hold a victory parade.

children.name: a victory lap
children.definition: when a winning runner or player runs around the playing area
examples: He then took a victory lap around the arena.

children.name: a string of victories
children.definition: a series of victories
examples: The team won a string of victories.

children.name: win
children.definition: when a team or playerwinsin a sport or competition - used especially innewsreports:
examples: We’ve had two wins so far this season.
It was United's sixth consecutive win this season.
Everyone was predicting a Republican win at the last election and look what happened.

children.name: a big win
children.definition: an important win, or one that you win by a large amount
examples: This is one of the biggest wins I’ve had.

children.name: an easy win
examples: The Australian appeared to be heading for an easy win.

children.name: a comfortable win
children.definition: one that you win by a large amount, so that you do not have to worry about winning
examples: Chelsea had a comfortable win against Crystal Palace.

children.name: a convincing winespecially British English
children.definition: a win by a large amount
examples: Scotland cruised to a convincing win over Ireland.

children.name: a five-point/two-goal etc win
examples: The team had a nine-point win over Arizona.

children.name: have/score a win
examples: We haven’t had a win for three games.

children.name: notch up a win
children.definition: achieve a win
examples: Escude has now notched up three consecutive wins over him.

children.name: pull off a win
children.definition: win when it is difficult to win
examples: The side has pulled off two excellent wins in the past couple of weeks.

children.name: clinch a win
children.definition: finally win after a difficult contest
examples: He suffered some anxious moments before clinching a 9–6 win over Dennis Taylor last night.

children.name: cruise to a win
children.definition: win easily
examples: Arsenal cruised to a win over Chelsea.

children.name: win over
examples: In the under-16 event England had their first win over Germany.

children.name: triumph
children.definition: an important victory after a long, difficult struggle, especially in war or politics: chiến thắng
examples: Despite many local triumphs, their party stands little chance of winning a national election.
Arsenal’s recent League Cup triumph.
Winning the championship is a greatpersonal triumph.
triumph for
a tremendousdiplomatic triumphfor France
triumph over
the triumph over hardship

children.name: success U
children.definition: success  a victory, especially in a series of games, fights etc:

children.name: thành công , chiến thắng ( đặc biệt trong 1 chuỗi trò chơi, cuộc chiến )
examples: ▪ With such a strong team, France are heading for certain success.

children.name: ▪ their fourth success in a row
conquest
children.definition: a victory in which one country wins a war against another countryand takes controlof it: chinh phục
examples: ▪ The palace was built in Cordoba, Spain, following the Arab conquest.
▪ The Roman legions left, opening the way for the conquest of the British Isles by the Germanic tribes.

children.name: walkover
children.definition: a situation in which someone wins veryeasily, especially in a sport, because they are much better than the people they are playing against: chiến thắng dễ dàng
examples: ▪ If they were expecting this game to be a walkover, they were very wrong.

children.name: landslide
children.definition: when one party or candidate getsfar morevotes than their opponents in anelection: thắng lớn
examples: ▪ The newspapers were predicting a landslide for Thatcher.

children.name: by a landslide
examples: ▪ He was re-elected in 1984 by a landslide.

children.name: landslide victory
examples: ▪ Few people had expected Labour’s landslide victory in 1945.

children.name: win easily
examples: ▪ Everyone expected the Democrats to win easily.

children.name: win something easily
examples: ▪ She won the race easily with seconds to spare.

children.name: win hands down
children.definition: to win very easily without having any problems:

children.name: thắng dễ dàng
examples: ▪ The Socialists will win hands down if the election is free and fair.
▪ The newer model wins hands down when it comes to speed and capacity.

children.name: be no contest U
children.definition: be no contest  if a game, competition etcis no contest, one person or team wins so easily that it is impossible for their opponent to win:
examples: ▪ In the end it was no contest. New Labour won more votes than even they thought possible.

children.name: run away with
children.definition: to win a game or competition very easily, especially because you are much better than your opponents:

children.name: chiến thắng ( dễ dàng vì mạnh hơn )
examples: ▪ United have esta blished a clear lead, and are threatening to run away with the championship.

children.name: be a shoo-in
children.definition: American to be verylikelyto easily win an election, competition etc, by having many more points, votes etc than you opponents:

children.name: là người chiến thắng ( rất có thể do đang chiếm được nhiều điểm, phiếu.. hơn )
examples: ▪ He looked like a shoo-in to win South Carolina’s Republican presidential primary.

children.name: sweep to victory
children.definition: to win very easily, in a way thatimpressespeople - used especiallyinnewsreports: thắng ngoạm mục, “lướt”
examples: ▪ Olson scored twice as the Rams swept to victory.
▪ Nixon swept to victory by 47 million votes to 29 million.

children.name: romp home
children.definition: British informal to win a race or game easily: thắng dễ dàng
examples: ▪ No goals were scored in the first half but Spurs romped home in the second, scoring four.

children.name: to win when you almost lost
win by a narrow margin
children.definition: if sb wins sth or is electedby a narrow margin, they win by getting only a few more points, votes etc than their opponent: thắng suýt sao
examples: We won the debate by a narrow margin.
Winning by a narrow margin, the Lakers now go on to play in the championships.

children.name: scrape home
children.definition: UK to win by a very small number of votes or points, or by a very small distance in a race: thắng suýt sao
examples: The Green Party scraped home in the local elections.
The referees decided that Foreman had just scraped home.

children.name: be close U
children.definition: be closealsobe a close-run thingUK  if a race, competition, election etc is close or is a close-run thing, any person or party could win because they all have nearly the same number of points, votes etc, or are close to each other in the race: gay cấn
examples: The election was very close - a handful of votes decided it.

children.name: The champions have kept their title, but it was a close-run thing
to be the one most expected to win
favourite
children.definition: be (the) British /be the favoriteAmerican   to be the person or team that everyone expects to win:
examples: be (the) favourite for
▪ The Danish runner was the favorite for the 100m sprint.
be (the) favourite to win
▪ Thatcher was favourite to win the 1983 election.
be (the) clear favourite
▪ The Luxembourg entry is clear favourite to win the Eurovision Song Contest.d

children.name: frontrunner
children.definition: the person or team that is most likely to win a race, election, or competition:

children.name: người , đội có tiềm năng chiến thắng
examples: ▪ He will certainly be a frontrunner in the Democratic primaries.
▪ The Greens have never really been among the frontrunners in British politics.

children.name: in the running
children.definition: be   to be one of the people whohas a good chanceof winning:

children.name: là người có cơ hội chiến thắng
examples: ▪ Spain still has several athletes in the running.

children.name: be in the running for
examples: ▪ Anthony Hopkins was in the running for an Oscar.

children.name: second
children.definition: ordinal number,determiner

children.name: the position in which a person finishes a race or competition if they finish immediately behind the winner
examples: _First prize is a fortnight inBarbadosand secondprizeis a weekend inRome.
_Jones took secondplacein the long jump.

children.name: second
children.definition: adverb

children.name: after the first and before any others
examples: _Robertson won the race and Cameronwas/came/finishedsecond.
_In this business, money comes first and principlescomea verypoorsecond (= they are much less important) .

children.name: come after/first/last, etc.
children.definition: to have or achieve a particular position in a race, competition, list, etc.
examples: _SheUKcame second/UScameinsecond in the 100m race.
_Z comesafterY in the alphabet.
_Which king cameafterEdward?
_April comesbeforeMay.
_I know the first verse of the song, but I don't know what comesnext.

children.name: lead
children.definition: verbled,ledBE WINNING dẫnđầu

children.name: lead
children.definition: nounBE WINNING vị trí đứng đầu

children.name: knock sb out
children.definition: knocksboutphrasal verbDEFEAT

children.name: to defeat a person or a team in a competition so that they can no longer take part in it
examples: _The champion was unexpectedly knocked out (ofthe tournament) in the first round.

children.name: come in first/second, etc
children.definition: .về vị trí thứ…
examples: to finish a race in first, second, etc. position
